transcripts.text: New tonight, we have the police dash cam videos that led to the firing of a police officer in Newark.  Derek Beach was fired in October for violating the department's pursuit policies and were told disobeying direct orders to disengage from a high-speed chase.  But as NBC4's Ted Hart tells us, Officer Beach insists he never was actually engaged in that pursuit.
It was a specific incident that brought it to a head, but a police review of Derek Beach's conduct concluded that there was a pattern that could not be ignored.

Despite what his cruiser dash cam shows, Officer Derek Beach insisted during an investigative interview that he was not engaged in the high-speed pursuit of a stolen tractor trailer last September 16th.

Being so many cars back, I wasn't actively trying to stop that vehicle.  I knew I wasn't going to stop the semi.  There was no point in time that I tried to rush up there and stop the semi.  There was nothing I could do to do that.

But speeding past a car in the left berm, doing a U-turn and cutting off several vehicles that were engaged in the pursuit, and continuing to drive at speeds over 100 miles per hour against direct orders not to engage in the pursuit... That was enough for the city's safety director, who wrote, I find that your decision-making process is fundamentally flawed, as demonstrated by your actions over not only this day, but other incidents in your career.  One of those other incidents involving Beach was this one, another high-speed pursuit documented by his dash cam, hitting speeds of 115 miles per hour, passing vehicles on the right, speeding through neighborhoods.

In his letter of termination, the safety director wrote to Beach that discipline is not used to punish but to change behavior.  But he adds, I do not believe discipline will have an effect on you.  Beach has the right to have a review of his termination by an arbitrator.  We were unable to reach him today for comment.  Local for you in Newark, Ted Hart, NBC4.
